channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: SEC sues Elon Musk, says he didn't disclose Twitter ownership on time before purchase
item.description: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission says Musk failed to disclose his ownership of Twitter stock in a timely manner before buying the site and underpaid by $150 million for shares he bought.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission says Musk failed to disclose his ownership of Twitter stock in a timely manner before buying the site and underpaid by $150 million for shares he bought.

(Image credit: Matt Rourke)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: No such thing as a free toilet: Starbucks reverses open bathroom policy
item.description: The new guideline is a reversal of a 2018 open-door policy that was implemented after two Black men, who had not ordered anything, were arrested at a Philadelphia store.
item.content:encoded:
The new guideline is a reversal of a 2018 open-door policy that was implemented after two Black men, who had not ordered anything, were arrested at a Philadelphia store.

(Image credit: Christopher Furlong)
item.dc:creator: Manuela LÃ³pez Restrepo

item.title: The FDA calls for at-a-glance nutrition labels on the front of packaged foods
item.description: The FDA wants front-of-package nutrition labels required on packaged foods. The labels would tell consumers if the product has Low, Medium or High levels of saturated fat, sodium and added sugar.
item.content:encoded:
The FDA wants front-of-package nutrition labels required on packaged foods. The labels would tell consumers if the product has Low, Medium or High levels of saturated fat, sodium and added sugar.

(Image credit: d3sign)
item.dc:creator: Maria Godoy

item.title: How the War is Straining Ukraine's Military and Shaping its Children
item.description: The city of Kherson in southern Ukraine is a key objective for Russia. Its military shells the city's neighborhoods daily and sends drones buzzing over the streets. We go out with a Ukrainian military unit that seeks to disrupt the Russians under the cover of darkness. And we also take a look at how three years of war have shaped Ukraine's children.
item.content:encoded: The city of Kherson in southern Ukraine is a key objective for Russia. Its military shells the city's neighborhoods daily and sends drones buzzing over the streets. We go out with a Ukrainian military unit that seeks to disrupt the Russians under the cover of darkness. And we also take a look at how three years of war have shaped Ukraine's children.
item.dc:creator: Brian Mann

item.title: Keeping America Safe: CIA Director Burns reflects
item.description:
On a shelf in his office at CIA headquarters, Director Bill Burns keeps a tiny scaled model of a house. It's the house in Kabul, Afghanistan, where Al Qaida leader Ayman al-Zawahiri was killed by a U.S. drone strike in 2022.

When NPR went out to interview him last week, Burns pointed to the exact balcony on which Zawahiri was standing. There was pride in his voice. The CIA had never stopped looking for the guy even more than two decades after 9/11.

But it was also a reminder of challenges, of adversaries that will outlast any single CIA director.

Now, as Burns wraps up four years running the Central Intelligence Agency, the challenges have multiplied and intensified.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org
item.content:encoded:
On a shelf in his office at CIA headquarters, Director Bill Burns keeps a tiny scaled model of a house. It's the house in Kabul, Afghanistan, where Al Qaida leader Ayman al-Zawahiri was killed by a U.S. drone strike in 2022.

When NPR went out to interview him last week, Burns pointed to the exact balcony on which Zawahiri was standing. There was pride in his voice. The CIA had never stopped looking for the guy even more than two decades after 9/11.

But it was also a reminder of challenges, of adversaries that will outlast any single CIA director.

Now, as Burns wraps up four years running the Central Intelligence Agency, the challenges have multiplied and intensified.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

(Image credit: Dee Dwyer for NPR)

item.title: Why some doctors have started asking patients about their spiritual lives
item.description: Indiana University's hospital system is pairing patients with local faith groups to ease feelings of loneliness and isolation. The unique new program comes as more doctors are seeing a need to care for patients' spiritual as well as physical health.
item.content:encoded:
Indiana University's hospital system is pairing patients with local faith groups to ease feelings of loneliness and isolation. The unique new program comes as more doctors are seeing a need to care for patients' spiritual as well as physical health.

(Image credit: Ben Thorp)
item.dc:creator: Ben Thorp

item.title: What's a 'Particularly Dangerous Situation' red flag warning and other wildfire terms
item.description: Here's a guide to understanding "particularly dangerous situation" red flag warnings, containment, and other terms related to the devastating fires that have left much of the LA area in ruins.
item.content:encoded:
Here's a guide to understanding "particularly dangerous situation" red flag warnings, containment, and other terms related to the devastating fires that have left much of the LA area in ruins.

(Image credit: Josh Edelson)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: The Princess of Wales says her cancer is in remission
item.description: The Princess of Wales revealed that her cancer is in remission after an emotional visit to the hospital where she received treatment last year.
item.content:encoded:
The Princess of Wales revealed that her cancer is in remission after an emotional visit to the hospital where she received treatment last year.

(Image credit: Chris Jackson)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: James Webb Space Telescope's 'little red dots' come into focus
item.description: A cosmic object spotted by the James Webb Space Telescope has flummoxed astronomers. Now, a research team has studied hundreds of these "little red dots" and found clues about their identity.
item.content:encoded:
A cosmic object spotted by the James Webb Space Telescope has flummoxed astronomers. Now, a research team has studied hundreds of these "little red dots" and found clues about their identity.

(Image credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI, Dale Kocevski (Colby College))
item.dc:creator: Nell Greenfieldboyce

item.title: 2 passenger jets came dangerously close to each other in the skies over Phoenix
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration is once again looking into a close call at a major U.S. airport, after two passenger jets narrowly avoided a mid-air collision as they attempted to land in Phoenix.
item.content:encoded:
The Federal Aviation Administration is once again looking into a close call at a major U.S. airport, after two passenger jets narrowly avoided a mid-air collision as they attempted to land in Phoenix.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose
